out loud. Word-by-word. Later, in the second grade, you were asked to read silently. But

You stopped reading out loud, but you continued to say every word to yourself.
Chances are, you're doing it right now.
This means that you read only as fast as you talk. About 250 to 300 words per minute.

speech on record: 327 words per minute.)
The Evelyn Wood Course teaches you to read without mentally saying each word to

With training, you'll learn to use your innate ability to see groups of words.

minute . . . depending on the difficulty of the material.

Political Tradition and finish each chapter in 11 minutes.

At 3,000 words per minute, you'll be able to read the 447 page novel

These are documented statistics based on the results of the 550,000

notes to take. And you don't have to memorize anything.
95% of our graduates have improved their reading ability by an
average of 4.7 times. On rare occasions, a graduate's reading ability

Bridging The Gap Demands
Initiative From The Top
The administrators and faculty who make
• policy concerning undergraduate education
lack a clear understanding of student opinion and often exhibit a disregard of student
interests. This year's Student Council realizes
this and is making an effort to bridge the gap
between students and administrators and
faculty with softball games and "take the
teacher to lunch week." While these efforts
are commendable, the problem will remain
until the administration and faculty take the
initiative to improve relations.
Important
policies
regarding
undergraduate education and student life at
Hopkins are generally formed without student input. From time to time, policy makers
attempt to gauge student opinion by reading
TheNews-Letter or consulting Student Council members. Yet these views can be rejected
or accepted at the discretion of the policy
makers. Student groups' lack of power and
influence has been reflected in several recent
issues. Last year, for instance, the Academic
Council voted to implement plus/minus
grading before learning that students were
overwhelmingly opposed to it. In the spring,
the same body allowed professors to give lectures or exams during reading week, again
ignoring student opinion. Even now, as the
administration decides how to allocate vacant offices in Levering Hall, the Student
Union, undergraduate concerns may not be
considered.
One reason that administrators and facul

ty offer in defense of student exclusion from
policy decisions is that students are transient.
They feel that because a different set of
undergraduates come to Hopkins every four
years that student attitudes shift radically
over long periods of time.
The News-Letter believes this to be false.
What concerns students today will likely still
concern them ten or twenty years from now,
barring any radical change in the type of
undergraduates Hopkins recruits. The very
basic educational, social, economic and
political needs of students do not fluctuate.
Unfortunately, students have few ways to
exert pressure on Hopkins policy makers.
Unless the political process is changed so as
to guarantee greater student involvement, we
must rely on the faculty and administrators
to increase their consideration of student
concerns and attitudes. The News-Letter
urges important administrators and
Academic Council members to take the initiative and actively seek student opinion.
The Academic Council should consult the
Committee on Undergraduate Studies and
the Student Council more frequently, and
make a concerted effort to meet with individual students on a regular basis. The Student Council is on the right track when it
organize events to foster closer ties between
the students and those who decide their fate.
Yet progress will probably be minimal until
the faculty and administration themselves
develop a new attitude and start to really
listen to the students.

The Consequences Of Porn At Hopkins
To the Editor:
While the controversy over
the senior class film series' intention to show the film "Deep
Throat" on October 15 and 16
seems to have come and gone
with relatively little uproar,
there are some important points
that your reporter ignored last
week that must be clarified.
First of all, Chris Hampton
and I spoke to Chris Columbo
and Mary Ellen Porter about
showing the movie, at which
time they advised us against
allowing it to be shown by the
Film Series. (Don't worry—
we're just as wise to the ways
of the world as the rest of you.)
The decision was left entirely up
to the senior class officers. In
addition, the reporter did not
examine the key issue of the
matter, which is he consequences of showing such a
movie and why the decision to
do so should not have been
made independently by the film
series chair people. It does not
seem too difficult to understand
why such a film has the potential to cause enormous problems; and for anyone to ignore
this is foolishness. We are not
talking about rights.
We do not live in a vacuum;
and those who favor showing
this film seem to conveniently
ignore that fact. First of all, the
film series is part of the senior
class, which is only a small part
of the entire university, which
is an important part of an entire community. Each group
has a certain obligation to the
others to behave responsibly,
and the decision of two individuals to shirk that responsibility without any consideration of its effects beyond the
premise that another X rated
movie was shown last year and
that "This will be a big
moneymaker" is absolutely
absurd.
There are important reasons
for not wanting to show "Deep
Throat." But more important
at this point is for everyone to
understand the impropriety of

BY CHARLES KRUZANSKV
The most important thing about the new
"Smorgasbord" in the Rotunda just north of
campus is that it is nothing like the Horn and
Horn cafeteria that was there for years. Don't
let any of those bad memories or disgusting
stories prevent you from going to this innovative
eating place.. The name that is used,
"Smorgasbord," is appropriate if only because
it cannot be called a restaurant or cafeteria. The
format is all-you-can-eat, but not just of one
Food or one special of the day, as was the case
in the old cafeteria. "The Smorgasbord" is allyou-can-eat of everything in a self-serve fashion.
The food is laid out in a long row that can be
approached from either side. There are always
seven main dishes, bread, soup, hot and cold
drinks, and several desserts including vanilla and
chocoiate ice cream and toppings.
The main dish area is always the first to be hit.
Among the main dishes available at a recent visit
were veal parmigiana, lasagna, fish cakes,
macaroni and cheese, and fried chicken.
The good variety of cooked and fresh
vegetables are always plentiful. The desserts consist of apple, peach, and blueberry with cake
combinations including some type of chocolate
cake,_ There _is soda, coffee, tea, milk, and an
assortment of fruit drinks.
For the strategist who knows what he wants
out of an all-you-can-eat establishment, the
"Smorgasbord" is the ultimate challenge. It is
very possible to get a very good meal there for

a very low price. Lunch, served every weekday
from 11:00 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. costs only $3.47
while dinner, served 4:00 to 8:00 p.m. weekdays
and all day Saturday and Sunday, is an
economical $4.95.
The main courses are the focal point of any
assault. They must be sampled and then the best
ones should be attacked at a moderate, constant
pace. Salads, breads, soups and vegetables
should be consumed in small portions to prevent
premature fullness.
The desserts are situated between the patron
and the main dishes, undoubtedly to tempt the
weaker and less skilled devourers into making a
sneak attack before the substantive foods have
been blitzed. These eye-pleasing and tasty
desserts are quite good. Nevertheless, they should
not be attacked before the main foods have been
thoroughly bombarded, nor can they be
assaulted on a full stomach. Careful deliberate
decisions are the key to optimizing effectivenes3
at the "Smorgasbord."
The relaxed, quiet, unrushed atmosphere is
conducive to tactical planning. The place is very
comfortable in this respect. Even the haphazard,
light eater has a good time there, it seems. The
food is wholesome, but not at all gourmet.
If you enjoy relaxed, unlimited, inexpensive
eating, then the Horn and Horn "Smorgasbord"
is the place for you to mark on your maps as the
next target. Bring your heaviest artillery because
the food keeps coming, and the variety makes
it difficult to anticipate the best courses of action.

The Childhood of Charle8Village
BY NORMA PEREZ
The Charles Village which was once considered afigment of Grace Darin's imagination
has so firmly rooted its identity as an intellectual enclave in Baltimore, that many are unaware
that it was born just fifteen years ago.
A good deal of the driving force behind
Peabody Heights' transition into Charles Village
in 1967 came from the fabrications of Grace
Darin, a villager dissatisfied with her area's lack
of identity and with its confusion over the
Peabody Conservatory area.
Grace Darin has resided in the Village since
the late 1940's and was, at the time, a reporter
for The Baltimore Sun. She convinced real estate
dealers that it would be profitable to plant promotions in their columns for a new center of intellectual creativity called Charles Village. Darin
described the yet-to-be Charles Village in a manner alluring to the youth of the 60's. When Darin
was asked by the elderly of the village why she
persisted in introducing such tomfoolery notions
in their, quiet, troublefree community, she
replied, "We have peace now, but it the peace
of the graveyard."
Charles Village became Darin's pet hobby. It
began as an indulgence which she planned to pursue for at least three years—time enough for any
substantial changes in the scheme of the Village
to become evident. The result was ten years of
dedicated expenditure of energy and money. For
example, Darin initiated, as well as financially

l'he Margaret Brent School.

sponsored, a newsletter which still circulates, as
one promotional device. She recalls feeling
strange when she saw one of her articles about
Charles Village make the cover of Sun Magazine
without having devised its appearance. Her
memories of reading this publication resemble
those of a mother witnessing the newborn she
had carried for so long. Enthusiam for Grace
Darin's child, Charles Village, spread like
wildfire.
As Darin had hoped, the young generation arrived in the village and caused a type of
intellectual revolution. Young parents brought
concern for a better educational system.
The Barkely-Brent Education Association was
formed to improve Barkely and Margaret Brent,
the two best grammar schools in the Village.

Photos by Richard Hara

Many designers were hired, and various grants
were received Tor a creative playground project.
Stan Edmeister, a sculptor and psychiatrist in
residency at Hopkins, analyzed the psychological
motivations of children at play there. Fellowships
were arranged for teachers from these two
schools to enroll in summer courses. Streets for
People, an organization Grace Darin refers to
as the "town guerilla group" waged the battle
to ease parking restrictions on St. Paul and
Maryland streets. Neighborhood House Tours
were established to encourage and display
renovations. The Civic Association held a
fleamarket for several years.
One of the most successful ventures in fundraising was the Charles Village Cookbook. It
was of a homemade, typed format that became
so popular that additional printings were required. The motivation behind the cookbook was
to tap into varied groups of people, cutting
across generational lines: everyone knows that
their grandmothers make the best oatmeal, that
men are natural-born barbecuers and chefs, and
even kids discover unique goodies by experimental combinations. Cookbook dinners were held
for people to bring dishes they had attempted.
Ten years later, a second edition containing Indian, Chinese, and international recipes missing
from the first volume was printed. These additions indicated that Charles Village had attracted
many students from abroad. Elderly people participated in the bustling culture of Charles Village
by writing journals of their pasts.
People living in Charles Village generally
relished the village's innovative character,
regardless of their initial motivations for coming. Grace Darin's ads attracted idealists as well
as materialistic individuals foreseeing increases-in
property value following the renovation of the
townhouses.
In 1968, just one year after the beginning of
Charles Village, Grace Darin looked out her window because she smelled smoke from the fires
during the Baltimore riots. She thought many
idealists and young parents would be frightened
away; but not one family she knew moved. Even
since mortgages have now become so difficult to
obtain, people still come in large numbers to rent
townhouses.

Bridging The Gap Demands
Initiative From The Top
The administrators and faculty who make
• policy concerning undergraduate education
lack a clear understanding of student opinion and often exhibit a disregard of student
interests. This year's Student Council realizes
this and is making an effort to bridge the gap
between students and administrators and
faculty with softball games and "take the
teacher to lunch week." While these efforts
are commendable, the problem will remain
until the administration and faculty take the
initiative to improve relations.
Important
policies
regarding
undergraduate education and student life at
Hopkins are generally formed without student input. From time to time, policy makers
attempt to gauge student opinion by reading
TheNews-Letter or consulting Student Council members. Yet these views can be rejected
or accepted at the discretion of the policy
makers. Student groups' lack of power and
influence has been reflected in several recent
issues. Last year, for instance, the Academic
Council voted to implement plus/minus
grading before learning that students were
overwhelmingly opposed to it. In the spring,
the same body allowed professors to give lectures or exams during reading week, again
ignoring student opinion. Even now, as the
administration decides how to allocate vacant offices in Levering Hall, the Student
Union, undergraduate concerns may not be
considered.
One reason that administrators and facul

ty offer in defense of student exclusion from
policy decisions is that students are transient.
They feel that because a different set of
undergraduates come to Hopkins every four
years that student attitudes shift radically
over long periods of time.
The News-Letter believes this to be false.
What concerns students today will likely still
concern them ten or twenty years from now,
barring any radical change in the type of
undergraduates Hopkins recruits. The very
basic educational, social, economic and
political needs of students do not fluctuate.
Unfortunately, students have few ways to
exert pressure on Hopkins policy makers.
Unless the political process is changed so as
to guarantee greater student involvement, we
must rely on the faculty and administrators
to increase their consideration of student
concerns and attitudes. The News-Letter
urges important administrators and
Academic Council members to take the initiative and actively seek student opinion.
The Academic Council should consult the
Committee on Undergraduate Studies and
the Student Council more frequently, and
make a concerted effort to meet with individual students on a regular basis. The Student Council is on the right track when it
organize events to foster closer ties between
the students and those who decide their fate.
Yet progress will probably be minimal until
the faculty and administration themselves
develop a new attitude and start to really
listen to the students.

The Consequences Of Porn At Hopkins
To the Editor:
While the controversy over
the senior class film series' intention to show the film "Deep
Throat" on October 15 and 16
seems to have come and gone
with relatively little uproar,
there are some important points
that your reporter ignored last
week that must be clarified.
First of all, Chris Hampton
and I spoke to Chris Columbo
and Mary Ellen Porter about
showing the movie, at which
time they advised us against
allowing it to be shown by the
Film Series. (Don't worry—
we're just as wise to the ways
of the world as the rest of you.)
The decision was left entirely up
to the senior class officers. In
addition, the reporter did not
examine the key issue of the
matter, which is he consequences of showing such a
movie and why the decision to
do so should not have been
made independently by the film
series chair people. It does not
seem too difficult to understand
why such a film has the potential to cause enormous problems; and for anyone to ignore
this is foolishness. We are not
talking about rights.
We do not live in a vacuum;
and those who favor showing
this film seem to conveniently
ignore that fact. First of all, the
film series is part of the senior
class, which is only a small part
of the entire university, which
is an important part of an entire community. Each group
has a certain obligation to the
others to behave responsibly,
and the decision of two individuals to shirk that responsibility without any consideration of its effects beyond the
premise that another X rated
movie was shown last year and
that "This will be a big
moneymaker" is absolutely
absurd.
There are important reasons
for not wanting to show "Deep
Throat." But more important
at this point is for everyone to
understand the impropriety of
the chain of events that has occured in relation to this movie.
Moral considerations aside,
(how anyone around here
chooses to get their thrills is
their own business) the point is
that the selection and planned
showing of this movie, without
any advice or consent from

those who may be offended,
was not a judicious decision.
The University does not currently have a film policy; supposedly on the premise that
those who show films have
enough discretion and common
sense to weigh the potential
merits and drawbacks of any
film they plan to show. An
event like this may change that,
which will bring all films under
the scrutiny of a limited and
structured set of rules.
Freedom of speech is one
thing, but inconsiderate and offensive actions are something
that I would like no part of.
Very truly yours,
Stephanie Kretchmer

Feast Awaits in The Rotunda
BY CHARLES KRUZANSKV
The most important thing about the new
"Smorgasbord" in the Rotunda just north of
campus is that it is nothing like the Horn and
Horn cafeteria that was there for years. Don't
let any of those bad memories or disgusting
stories prevent you from going to this innovative
eating place.. The name that is used,
"Smorgasbord," is appropriate if only because
it cannot be called a restaurant or cafeteria. The
format is all-you-can-eat, but not just of one
Food or one special of the day, as was the case
in the old cafeteria. "The Smorgasbord" is allyou-can-eat of everything in a self-serve fashion.
The food is laid out in a long row that can be
approached from either side. There are always
seven main dishes, bread, soup, hot and cold
drinks, and several desserts including vanilla and
chocoiate ice cream and toppings.
The main dish area is always the first to be hit.
Among the main dishes available at a recent visit
were veal parmigiana, lasagna, fish cakes,
macaroni and cheese, and fried chicken.
The good variety of cooked and fresh
vegetables are always plentiful. The desserts consist of apple, peach, and blueberry with cake
combinations including some type of chocolate
cake,_ There _is soda, coffee, tea, milk, and an
assortment of fruit drinks.
For the strategist who knows what he wants
out of an all-you-can-eat establishment, the
"Smorgasbord" is the ultimate challenge. It is
very possible to get a very good meal there for

a very low price. Lunch, served every weekday
from 11:00 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. costs only $3.47
while dinner, served 4:00 to 8:00 p.m. weekdays
and all day Saturday and Sunday, is an
economical $4.95.
The main courses are the focal point of any
assault. They must be sampled and then the best
ones should be attacked at a moderate, constant
pace. Salads, breads, soups and vegetables
should be consumed in small portions to prevent
premature fullness.
The desserts are situated between the patron
and the main dishes, undoubtedly to tempt the
weaker and less skilled devourers into making a
sneak attack before the substantive foods have
been blitzed. These eye-pleasing and tasty
desserts are quite good. Nevertheless, they should
not be attacked before the main foods have been
thoroughly bombarded, nor can they be
assaulted on a full stomach. Careful deliberate
decisions are the key to optimizing effectivenes3
at the "Smorgasbord."
The relaxed, quiet, unrushed atmosphere is
conducive to tactical planning. The place is very
comfortable in this respect. Even the haphazard,
light eater has a good time there, it seems. The
food is wholesome, but not at all gourmet.
If you enjoy relaxed, unlimited, inexpensive
eating, then the Horn and Horn "Smorgasbord"
is the place for you to mark on your maps as the
next target. Bring your heaviest artillery because
the food keeps coming, and the variety makes
it difficult to anticipate the best courses of action.

The Childhood of Charle8Village
BY NORMA PEREZ
The Charles Village which was once considered afigment of Grace Darin's imagination
has so firmly rooted its identity as an intellectual enclave in Baltimore, that many are unaware
that it was born just fifteen years ago.
A good deal of the driving force behind
Peabody Heights' transition into Charles Village
in 1967 came from the fabrications of Grace
Darin, a villager dissatisfied with her area's lack
of identity and with its confusion over the
Peabody Conservatory area.
Grace Darin has resided in the Village since
the late 1940's and was, at the time, a reporter
for The Baltimore Sun. She convinced real estate
dealers that it would be profitable to plant promotions in their columns for a new center of intellectual creativity called Charles Village. Darin
described the yet-to-be Charles Village in a manner alluring to the youth of the 60's. When Darin
was asked by the elderly of the village why she
persisted in introducing such tomfoolery notions
in their, quiet, troublefree community, she
replied, "We have peace now, but it the peace
of the graveyard."
Charles Village became Darin's pet hobby. It
began as an indulgence which she planned to pursue for at least three years—time enough for any
substantial changes in the scheme of the Village
to become evident. The result was ten years of
dedicated expenditure of energy and money. For
example, Darin initiated, as well as financially

l'he Margaret Brent School.

sponsored, a newsletter which still circulates, as
one promotional device. She recalls feeling
strange when she saw one of her articles about
Charles Village make the cover of Sun Magazine
without having devised its appearance. Her
memories of reading this publication resemble
those of a mother witnessing the newborn she
had carried for so long. Enthusiam for Grace
Darin's child, Charles Village, spread like
wildfire.
As Darin had hoped, the young generation arrived in the village and caused a type of
intellectual revolution. Young parents brought
concern for a better educational system.
The Barkely-Brent Education Association was
formed to improve Barkely and Margaret Brent,
the two best grammar schools in the Village.

Photos by Richard Hara

Many designers were hired, and various grants
were received Tor a creative playground project.
Stan Edmeister, a sculptor and psychiatrist in
residency at Hopkins, analyzed the psychological
motivations of children at play there. Fellowships
were arranged for teachers from these two
schools to enroll in summer courses. Streets for
People, an organization Grace Darin refers to
as the "town guerilla group" waged the battle
to ease parking restrictions on St. Paul and
Maryland streets. Neighborhood House Tours
were established to encourage and display
renovations. The Civic Association held a
fleamarket for several years.
One of the most successful ventures in fundraising was the Charles Village Cookbook. It
was of a homemade, typed format that became
so popular that additional printings were required. The motivation behind the cookbook was
to tap into varied groups of people, cutting
across generational lines: everyone knows that
their grandmothers make the best oatmeal, that
men are natural-born barbecuers and chefs, and
even kids discover unique goodies by experimental combinations. Cookbook dinners were held
for people to bring dishes they had attempted.
Ten years later, a second edition containing Indian, Chinese, and international recipes missing
from the first volume was printed. These additions indicated that Charles Village had attracted
many students from abroad. Elderly people participated in the bustling culture of Charles Village
by writing journals of their pasts.
People living in Charles Village generally
relished the village's innovative character,
